newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Deng rumours spook Singapore stock market down.
newsitem.headline: Deng rumours spook Singapore stock market down.

text.p: Mounting concerns over the health of Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping sent the Singapore stock market lower on Tuesday.
Small-capitalised stocks like SMB United and Malaysian shares like MBf Holdings remained active although volumes were not as hectic as previous weeks, dealers said.

"The focus is more on specific stock fundamentals today," said a dealer. "Those that have retraced are expected to post disappointing earnings next month." Property developer City Development, shipping conglomerate Sembawang and selected banks were among losers, shedding Singapore $0.30 (US$0.21) to S$0.50. The Straits Times Industrials Index fell 26.31 points to 2,229.79. Turnover was moderate around 337 million shares, with losers outpacing gainers by 375 to 69.
SMB United topped the actives with over 17 million shares on punters' interest, dealers said.

CM Telecom was up US$0.015 at US$0.38 in active trade on a buy recommendation by a research house based on the paging firm's good growth prospects. There was still lingering foreign interest which drove selected blue chips higher.
Dealers said Singapore's 1996 growth data released on Tuesday did not impact the market.
